content.text: 1 (a) Define gravitational potential at a point
(i) Show that the mass of Mars is \(6.4 \times 10^{23} \mathrm{~kg}\)
(ii) Calculate the gravitational potential \(\phi\) at the surface of Mars. Give a unit with your answer
(b) Mars is a planet that may be considered to be an isolated uniform sphere of radius \(3.4 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m}\)
A satellite of mass 122 kg is in orbit around Mars at a constant height of \(1.7 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m}\) above the surface of the planet
The height of the orbit is increased to \(6.8 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m}\) above the surface. This increases the gravitational potential energy of the satellite by \(5.1 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~J}\)
(i) The orbit has a period of 25 hours
State what can be deduced from this about the rotation of Mars on its axis
(ii) State one other feature of this orbit
(c) The satellite in (b) is moved to an orbit in which the satellite remains at the same point above the surface of Mars
(a) State Coulomb's law
(b) (i) State the charge on the nucleus, in terms of the elementary charge \(e\)
charge = e
(ii) Show that the electric force between the nucleus and one of the electrons is \(1.6 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~N}\)
(i) Calculate the speed of the orbiting electrons
speed = \(\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\)
(ii) Calculate the period of the orbit of the electrons
period = \(\mathrm{s}\)
(c) Assume that the force in (b)(ii) is the only force on the electrons
(i) For the position of one of the electrons, determine the ratio
electric field strength due to the other electron electric field strength due to the nucleus
ratio =
(ii) Use your answer in (d)(i) to suggest and explain how the orbit of the electron is affected by the presence of the other electron
(d) In practice, the orbit of each electron is affected by the presence of the other electron
2 A helium atom may be modelled as a nucleus surrounded by two electrons in diametrically opposite circular orbits, each of radius 170 pm, as shown in Fig. 2.1
3 (a) Define specific latent heat
(b) Explain why, for a substance, the specific latent heat of vaporisation is usually greater than the specific latent heat of fusion
(c) An ice cube of mass 37.0 g at temperature \(0.0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) is placed in a beaker containing water of mass 208 g at temperature \(26.4^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
When all the ice has melted, and all the water in the beaker has reached thermal equilibrium, the final temperature of all the water is \(10.3^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
The specific heat capacity of water is \(4.18 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~g}^{-1}{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}^{-1}\)
The beaker has negligible specific heat capacity and is perfectly insulated from the surroundings
Determine a value, to three significant figures, for the specific latent heat of fusion of water
specific latent heat of fusion \(=\) \(\mathrm{Jg}^{-1}\)
4 (a) (i) State what is meant by the internal energy of a system
(ii) Explain why the internal energy of an ideal gas is directly proportional to the thermodynamic temperature of the gas
(b) A sample of an ideal gas at thermodynamic temperature \(T\) has internal energy \(U\)
The gas is compressed so that its temperature increases to 3 \(T\)
During this compression, work \(W\) is done on the gas
The gas is then cooled at constant volume so that its temperature decreases to 2 \(T\)

Complete Table 4.1 to show, in terms of some or all of \(W, T\) and \(U\), the work done on the gas, the thermal energy supplied to the gas and the increase in internal energy of the gas for each of the two processes

table.html:
work done on gasthermal energy supplied to gasincrease in internal energy of gas
compression\(+W\)
cooling

content.text: [Total: 8]
(a) (i) Determine the amplitude of the oscillations
amplitude = m
(ii) State what the line in Fig. 5.2 shows about the nature of the oscillations
(b) State three other quantitative conclusions that can be drawn from Fig. 5.2 and Fig. 5.3 about the block and its oscillations. Use the space for any working
(c) On Fig. 5.4, sketch the variation with \(h\) of the potential energy \(E_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the oscillations
5 A cuboidal block floats in a liquid with its base horizontal, as shown in Fig. 5.1
The base of the block is at a depth \(h\) below the surface of the liquid
The block is displaced downwards by a small distance and then released so that it oscillates
Fig. 5.2 shows the variation with \(h\) of the acceleration \(a\) of the block
Fig. 5.3 shows the variation with \(h\) of the kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) of the block
(a) (i) State what is meant by rectification
(ii) State the purpose of capacitor C
(i) The variation of \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) with \(t\) can be represented by
where \(A\) and \(B\) are constants
Determine the values of \(A\) and \(B\). Give a unit with your answer for \(A\)
(ii) Determine the type of rectification produced by the circuit in Fig. 6.1
(iii) On Fig. 6.3, draw the circuit diagram for the components inside the rectification circuit
(iv) Determine a value for the time constant for the discharge of the capacitor C through the resistor R in Fig. 6.1
(b) Fig. 6.2 shows the variations with time \(t\) of the potential differences (p.d.s) \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) and \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\)
(c) The capacitor \(C\) has a capacitance of \(570 \mu \mathrm{~F}\)
Use your answer in (b)(iv) to determine the resistance of resistor \(R\)
resistance = \(\Omega\)
[Total: 12]
6 Fig. 6.1 shows a circuit that rectifies an alternating input voltage \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) and produces an output voltage \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\) across a resistor R
The four terminals of the rectification circuit are labelled W, X, Y and Z
A capacitor C is connected in parallel with resistor R
7 (a) Define magnetic flux density
(i) State an expression, in terms of some or all of \(m, Q, B\) and \(v\), for the magnetic force \(F\) that acts on the particle when it is at point Y
(b) A particle of mass \(m\) and charge \(+Q\) moves at speed \(v\) into a region where there is a uniform magnetic field, as shown in Fig. 7.1
The uniform magnetic field is into the page and has flux density \(B\). The particle enters the region of the field at point Y
8 (a) State what is meant by the de Broglie wavelength
(b) Calculate the de Broglie wavelength of an electron moving at a speed of \(4.9 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\)
wavelength = m
(c) State one similarity and one difference between an electron and a positron
similarity:
difference:
(i) State the name of this type of reaction
(ii) State what happens to the electron and to the positron
(iii) Explain why two gamma-ray photons are produced, rather than just one
(iv) Show that the kinetic energy of the electron before the collision is \(1.1 \times 10^{-15} \mathrm{~J}\)
(v) Use the information in (d)(iv) to determine, to three significant figures, the wavelength associated with the gamma radiation emitted in the collision
wavelength = m

(d) An electron moving at a speed of \(4.9 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) collides with a positron that is travelling at the same speed in the opposite direction. As a result of the collision, two gamma-ray photons are produced
9 (a) Define activity of a radioactive sample
(b) Explain why the variation with time of the activity of a radioactive sample is exponential in nature
(i) Determine the decay constant, in \(\mathrm{min}^{-1}\), of the radioactive isotope
decay constant = \(\mathrm{min}^{-1}\)
(ii) Use your answer in (c)(i) to determine the half-life, in min, of the radioactive isotope
(iii) On Fig. 9.1, sketch the variation of the activity \(A\) of the sample with \(t\) for values of \(t\) between \(t=0\) and \(t=24 \mathrm{~min}\)
(c) A sample contains a single radioactive isotope that decays to form a stable isotope
The sample has an activity of 180 Bq at time \(t=0\)
At a time 8.4 minutes later, the activity is 120 Bq
10 (a) State Hubble's law
(i) Explain why the observed wavelength and the emitted wavelength have different values
(ii) Calculate the speed of the star relative to the Earth
speed = \(\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\)
(iii) The wavelength of maximum intensity of emission is used to determine a value for the surface temperature of the star
Explain how the temperature determined using the observed wavelength compares with the true value of temperature determined using the emitted wavelength
(b) A star in a distant galaxy emits radiation that has a maximum intensity of emission at a wavelength of \(4.62 \times 10^{-7} \text{m}\)
Observations of the galaxy made on the Earth detect the maximum intensity of emission from the star at a wavelength of \(4.91 \times 10^{-7} \text{m}\)
(c) A value for the Hubble constant is \(2.3 \times 10^{-18} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\)
Use your answer in (b)(ii) to determine the distance of the star in (b) from the Earth
distance = m
